trees.nature: The perfect home for iconic Scottish wildlife, such as the red squirrel, capercaillie, Scottish crossbill and the Scottish wildcat

Common juniper provides dense cover for nesting birds, such as the goldcrest and firecrest, and, in northern upland areas, the black grouse. A number of birds eat the fruit, including the fieldfare, song thrush, mistle thrush and ring ouzel.
Provides food and habitat for over 300 different types of insects. The seeds are food for siskins, greenfinches and redpolls
Provides food and habitat for over 300 different types of insects. The seeds are food for siskins, greenfinches and redpolls
The roots make perfect nests for otters and the seeds are eaten by siskin, redpoll and goldfinch.

Oak trees support more wildlife than other trees, eg the deadwood cavities providing habitats for nesting birds and roosting bats. Food plants of caterpillars of purples hairstreak butterflies. Squirrels, jays and badgers eat their acorns.

Due to their size, they provide perfect cover for wildflowers which in turn support a wide range of insects including the rare high brown fritillery butterfly. Woodpeckers, owls, redstarts and nuthatches use the tree for nesting.

Coppiced hazel also provides shelter for ground-nesting birds, such as the nightingale, nightjar, yellowhammer and willow warbler. Hazel has long been associated with the dormouse (also known as the hazel dormouse). Not only are hazelnuts eaten by dormice to fatten up for hibernation, but in spring the leaves are a good source of caterpillars, which dormice also eat. Hazelnuts are also eaten by woodpeckers, nuthatches, tits, wood pigeons, jays and small mammals. Hazel flowers provide early pollen as a food for bees.

Grey willow foliage is eaten by caterpillars of a number of moths, including the sallow kitten, sallow clearwing, dusky clearwing and lunar hornet clearwing. It is also a food plant for the purple emperor butterfly. Catkins provide an important early source of pollen and nectar for bees and other insects, and birds use grey willow to forage for caterpillars and insects

The main food plant for the purple emperor butterfly. Catkins provide an important early source of pollen and nectar for bees and other insects, and birds use goat willow to forage for caterpillars and insects.

Flowers provide pollen and nectar for bees and other pollinating insects, while the berries are a rich source of autumn food for birds, especially the blackbird, mistle thrush, redstart, redwing, song thrush, fieldfare and waxwing
Aspen are the preferred species for beavers, and provide nesting opportunities for birds such as the woodpecker
Many birds eat the seeds and leaves provide food for caterpillars of many moths, and the caterpillar of the white-letter hairstreak butterfly
The haws are eaten by migrating birds, such as redwings, fieldfares and thrushes. The foliage makes fantastic nesting shelters for many species of birds

The leaves provide great nesting opportunities for birds and the dry leaf litter can be used for hibernation by hedgehogs and other small mammals. Deer eat the smooth leaves at the top, and berries are a vital food source during winter for birds and small mammals
Dormice and bank voles eat both the fruit and flowers, berries are eaten by many insects and animals, fruit provides nectar and pollen. Caterpillars and moths.
Provides nectar and pollen for bees. Cherries are eaten by birds such as blackbirds and song thrush, and mammals such as badger, wood mouse, yellow-necked mouse and dormouse
Provides nectar and pollen for bees. Cherries are eaten by birds such as blackbirds and song thrush, and mammals such as badger, wood mouse, yellow-necked mouse and dormouse

The flowers provide an important source of early pollen and nectar for bees and other insects. The fruit is eaten by birds such as thrushes, blackbirds and crows, and mammals such as mice, voles, foxes and badgers
Dog rose flowers are an important nectar source for insects and its fruits are a food source for birds such as blackbirds, redwings and waxwings.

Arran whitebeam produces good pollen when growing in favourable conditions. The wild deer love the leaves (which is one of the reasons the tree population is struggling) and birds eat the ripe berries.
